Introduction</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S2\" title=\"Compiled list of gravitationally lensed quasars\">2. Compiled list ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S3\" title=\"Gravitationally lensed quasars in Gaia DR2\">3. Gravitationally lensed ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S4\" title=\"Astrometric properties of the Gaia DR2 gravitationally lensed quasars\">4. Astrometric properties ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S5\" title=\"Gravitational lens modelling with sub-mas astrometry\">5. Gravitational lens ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S6\">6. Conclusions</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#ack\">Acknowledgments</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#ref\">References</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#app\">Appendix A:</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#tabs\">List of tables</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#figs\">List of figures</a></li>\n</ul></div>\n<div id=\"contenu\">\n<a name=\"top_full\"></a><div id=\"head\">A&amp;A 618, A56 (2018)<h2 class=\"title\">\n<i>Gaia</i> GraL: <i>Gaia</i> DR2 gravitational lens systems</h2>\n<h3 class=\"subtitle\">II. The known multiply imaged quasars<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#FN1\">&#8902;</a></sup>\n</h3>\n<div class=\"article-authors\"><p class=\"bold\"><span id=\"aa33480-18-author-1\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=1\" class=\"author author-orcid\">C. Ducourant</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-2\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=2\" class=\"author\">O. Wertz</span><sup>2</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-3\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=3\" class=\"author\">A. Krone-Martins</span><sup>3</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-4\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=4\" class=\"author\">R. Teixeira</span><sup>4</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-5\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=5\" class=\"author\">J.-F. Le Campion</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-6\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=6\" class=\"author\">L. Galluccio</span><sup>5</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-7\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=7\" class=\"author\">J. Kl&#252;ter</span><sup>6</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-8\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=8\" class=\"author\">L. Delchambre</span><sup>7</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-9\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=9\" class=\"author\">J. Surdej</span><sup>7</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-10\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=10\" class=\"author\">F. Mignard</span><sup>5</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-11\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=11\" class=\"author\">J. Wambsganss</span><sup>6</sup><sup>,9</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-12\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=12\" class=\"author\">U. Bastian</span><sup>6</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-13\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=13\" class=\"author\">M. J. Graham</span><sup>8</sup>, <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-14\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=14\" class=\"author\">S. G. Djorgovski</span><sup>8</sup> and <span id=\"aa33480-18-author-15\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480&amp;n=15\" class=\"author\">E. Slezak</span><sup>5</sup></p></div>\n<p class=\"aff\">\n<sup>1</sup> \n \nLaboratoire d&#8217;Astrophysique de Bordeaux, Univ. Bordeaux, CNRS, B18N, all&#233;e Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 33615   Pessac,  France \n\n<br>e-mail: christine.ducourant@u-bordeaux.fr<br>\n<sup>2</sup> \n \nArgelander-Institut f&#252;r Astronomie, Universit&#228;t Bonn, Auf dem H&#252;gel 71, 53121   Bonn,  Germany \n<br>\n<sup>3</sup> \n \nCENTRA, Faculdade de Ci&#234;ncias, Universidade de Lisboa, Ed. C8, Campo Grande, 1749-016   Lisboa,  Portugal \n<br>\n<sup>4</sup> \n \nInstituto de Astronomia, Geof&#237;sica e Ci&#234;ncias Atmosf&#233;ricas, Universidade de S&#227;o Paulo, Rua do Mat&#227;o, 1226, Cidade Universit&#225;ria, 05508-900  S&#227;o Paulo, SP,  Brazil \n<br>\n<sup>5</sup> \n \nUniversit&#233; C&#244;te d&#8217;Azur, Observatoire de la C&#244;te d&#8217;Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire Lagrange, Boulevard de l&#8217;Observatoire, CS 34229, 06304 Nice,  France \n<br>\n<sup>6</sup> \n \nZentrum f&#252;r Astronomie der Universit&#228;t Heidelberg, Astronomisches Rechen-Institut, M&#246;nchhofstr. 12-14, 69120   Heidelberg,  Germany \n<br>\n<sup>7</sup> \n \nInstitut d&#8217;Astrophysique et de G&#233;ophysique, Universit&#233; de Li&#232;ge, 19c, All&#233;e du 6 Ao&#251;t, 4000   Li&#232;ge,  Belgium \n<br>\n<sup>8</sup> \n \n California Institute of Technology, 1200 E. California Blvd, Pasadena, CA 91125,  USA \n<br>\n<sup>9</sup> \n \n International Space Science Institute (ISSI), Hallerstra&#223;e 6, 3012   Bern,  Switzerland \n<br></p>\n<p class=\"history\"><span class=\"bold\">Received: </span>\n23 \nMay \n2018\n<br><span class=\"bold\">Accepted: </span>\n2 \nJuly \n2018\n</p>\n<p class=\"bold\"><a name=\"abs\"></a>Abstract</p>\n<p><i>Context</i>. Thanks to its spatial resolution, the ESA/<i>Gaia</i> space mission offers a unique opportunity to discover new multiply imaged quasars and to study the already known lensed systems at sub-milliarcsecond astrometric precisions.</p>\n<p><i>Aims</i>. In this paper, we address the detection of the known multiply imaged quasars from the <i>Gaia</i> Data Release 2 (DR2) and determine the astrometric and photometric properties of the individually detected images found in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 catalogue.</p>\n<p><i>Methods</i>. We have compiled an exhaustive list of quasar gravitational lenses from the literature to search for counterparts in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2. We then analysed the astrometric and photometric properties of these <i>Gaia</i>&#8217;s detections. To highlight the tremendous potential of <i>Gaia</i> at the sub-milliarcsecond level we finally performed a simple Bayesian modelling of the well-known gravitational lens system HE0435-1223, using <i>Gaia</i> DR2 and HST astrometry.</p>\n<p><i>Results</i>. From 481 known multiply imaged quasars, 206 have at least one image found in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2. Among the 44 known quadruply imaged quasars of the list, 29 have at least one image in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2, 12 of which are fully detected (2MASX J01471020+4630433, HE 0435-1223, SDSS1004+4112, PG1115+080, RXJ1131-1231, 2MASS J11344050-2103230, 2MASS J13102005-1714579, B1422+231, J1606-2333, J1721+8842, WFI2033-4723, WGD2038-4008), eight have three counterparts, eight have two and one has only one. As expected, the modelling of HE0435-1223 shows that the model parameters are significantly better constrained when using <i>Gaia</i> astrometry compared to HST astrometry, in particular the relative positions of the background quasar source and the centroid of the deflector. The <i>Gaia</i> sub-milliarcsecond astrometry also significantly reduces the parameter correlations.</p>\n<p><i>Conclusions</i>. Besides providing an up-to-date list of multiply imaged quasars and their detection in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2, this paper shows that more complex modelling scenarios will certainly benefit from <i>Gaia</i> sub-milliarcsecond astrometry.</p>\n<div class=\"kword\"><p><span class=\"bold\">Key words: </span>gravitational lensing: strong / astrometry</p></div>\n<div class=\"note\">\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div>\n<a name=\"FN1\"></a><sup>&#8902;</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">The table of lenses (confirmed and candidates, detected or not in <i>Gaia</i> DR2) is only available at the CDS via anonymous ftp to <a href=\"http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr\" target=\"_blank\">cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr</a> (<a href=\"ftp://130.79.128.5\" target=\"_blank\">130.79.128.5</a>) or via <a href=\"http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/qcat?J/A+A/618/A56\" target=\"_blank\">http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/qcat?J/A+A/618/A56</a>. A subset of this table is presented in Table B.1.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><i>&#169; ESO 2018</i></p>\n<p><a rel=\"license\" href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0\"><img alt=\"Licence Creative Commons\" src=\"https://i.creativecommons.org/l/by/4.0/88x31.png\"></a><br>Open Access article, <a href=\"http://www.edpsciences.org\" target=\"_blank\">published by EDP Sciences</a>, under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License (<a href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0\" target=\"_blank\">http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0</a>), which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S1\"></a>1. Introduction</h2>\n<p>The ESA/<i>Gaia</i> space mission (<a name=\"InR27\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R27\">Gaia Collaboration 2016b</a>) constitutes an exceptional opportunity to characterise and to discover multiply imaged quasars, although this was not put forth as one of the science objectives in the mission proposal. With a spatial resolution of &#8764;0.18&#8243; <i>Gaia</i> is roughly comparable to that of <i>Hubble</i> Space Telescope (HST) for this particular feature (e.g. <a name=\"InR10\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R10\">Bellini et al. 2011</a>). However <i>Gaia</i> being a scanning mission is unique in providing an all-sky coverage with that angular resolution. Thus, by the final <i>Gaia</i> data release (DR), a whole population of such multiply imaged quasars would be revealed, providing an all-sky, and the first of this kind, survey of multiply imaged quasars with well understood source detection biases (e.g. <a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R19\">de Bruijne et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR7\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R7\">Arenou et al. 2017</a>, <a name=\"InR8\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R8\">2018</a>).</p>\n<p>Several programmes dedicated to systematic searches for lenses in large astronomical surveys such as SDSS, WISE, DES, PanSTARRS, among others, have been developed in recent years (e.g. <a name=\"InR73\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R73\">More et al. 2016</a>, <a name=\"InR74\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R74\">2017</a>; <a name=\"InR64\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R64\">Lin et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR61\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R61\">Ostrovski et al. 2018</a>), and many of them rely on supervised machine learning algorithms trained on simulations to handle the large volume of imaging data (e.g. <a name=\"InR86\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R86\">Petrillo et al. 2017</a>; Perreault <a name=\"InR85\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R85\">Levasseur et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR34\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R34\">Hartley et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR88\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R88\">Pourrahmani et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR56\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R56\">Lanusse et al. 2018</a>). Naturally, even if <i>Gaia</i> does not provide images of the observed sources, contrary to the previously mentioned surveys, its high angular resolution over the entire sky is a major asset to contribute to the discovery and the study of multiply imaged quasars.</p>\n<p><a name=\"InR24\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R24\">Finet &amp; Surdej (2016)</a> investigate the potential of <i>Gaia</i> for gravitational lensing and compared it to the detectability with seeing-limited observations for the same limiting magnitude (<i>G</i> = 20). They expect at maximum about &#8764;1600 multiply imaged quasars with an angular separation large enough to be resolved from the ground in an optimal seeing scenario, while scarcely &#8764;80 would be composed by more than two images. However, they predict that detections from space are much more encouraging, raising the number of multiply imaged quasars detectable by a <i>Gaia</i>-like survey to &#8764;2900, thanks to the improved resolving power alone.</p>\n<p>The first <i>Gaia</i> data release (DR1; <a name=\"InR26\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R26\">Gaia Collaboration 2016a</a>), besides providing the best available two-parameter astrometry (positions only) at the epoch of its publication, contained only one <i>G</i> mean magnitude, and it did not reach the effective angular resolution necessary to include most of the multiply imaged quasars. This happened due to data processing issues and final astrometric quality reasons (<a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R22\">Fabricius et al. 2016</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R7\">Arenou et al. 2017</a>). Yet, several multiply imaged quasars discovered from other large surveys such as Pan-STARRS, DES, SDSS-III BOSS, HSCS or VST-ATLAS, were subsequently identified with at least one <i>Gaia</i> DR1 detection (e.g. <a name=\"InR1\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R1\">Agnello et al. 2015</a>, <a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R2\">2017</a>, <a name=\"InR4\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R4\">2018b</a>; <a name=\"InR60\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R60\">Lemon et al. 2017</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R61\">2018</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R61\">Ostrovski et al. 2018</a>).</p>\n<p>The <i>Gaia</i> DR2 (<a name=\"InR28\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R28\">Gaia Collaboration 2018</a>) on the other hand, starts to deliver colour information and thus to become self-sufficient in the search for new lenses. It also starts to reach effective angular resolutions that are capable of resolving more multiply imaged quasars, expected with typical separations below 1&#8243;. The <i>Gaia</i> DR2 effective resolution reaches &#8764;0.4&#8243;, with completeness for separations larger than &#8764;2.2&#8243; (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R28\">Gaia Collaboration 2018</a>). However this resolution applies strictly only to astrometry and <i>G</i> band photometry; colour data are available for objects with separations down to &#8764;2&#8243;, but its completeness only reaches &#8764;3.5&#8243; (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R28\">Gaia Collaboration 2018</a>). Even if it is still far from the ultimate resolving power of the <i>Gaia</i> instrument, the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 is a significant advance over DR1, as beyond its much improved effective angular resolution, it contains five-parameter astrometric data (positions, proper-motions, parallax) and also colour information for most objects. This significantly simplifies the extraction of genuine extragalactic sources from the galactic stellar contaminants. Only the faintest or most problematic objects are characterised by just a two-parameters solution in this data release, which is unfortunately the case for several multiply imaged quasars as their magnitudes are often close to the <i>Gaia</i> limiting sensitivity at (<i>G</i> &#8764; 20.7).</p>\n<p>As part of a larger effort to discover and study multiply imaged quasar candidates from the various <i>Gaia</i> data releases, our group first searched for new lensed systems around known or candidate quasars, enabling the discovery of highly probable multiply imaged quasar candidates for the first time from <i>Gaia</i> data alone (<i>Gaia</i> GraL Paper I; <a name=\"InR55\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R55\">Krone-Martins et al. 2018</a>). In the present work, we report our findings regarding the identification of known gravitationally lensed quasars in <i>Gaia</i> DR2. We have analysed the statistical astrometric properties of the detected lensed images and provide improved relative astrometry for them. We also derive soft astrometric filters that will be applied, as part of a global blind search (<i>Gaia</i> GraL Paper III; Delchambre et al., in prep.), to differentiate foreground stars from extragalactic objects without rejecting the faint components of known lensed systems. To illustrate how the exquisite optical astrometry of <i>Gaia</i> at the sub-milliarcsecond level may help to better constrain the lenses, we performed a simple modelling of the quadruple lens HE0435-1223 in a Bayesian framework, both using <i>Gaia</i> and HST astrometry, for comparison purposes.</p>\n<p>The paper is organised as follows: in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S2\">2</a> we describe the construction of our list of gravitationally lensed quasars and candidates from published data. Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S3\">3</a> presents the matching statistics of this list of known systems with the <i>Gaia</i> DR2. Section <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S4\">4</a> presents the astrometric properties of the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 data for the known systems. A simple modelling within the Bayesian framework of a known lens using <i>Gaia</i> DR2 astrometry is described and discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S5\">5</a>. Finally, we summarise our findings in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S6\">6</a>.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. Compiled list of gravitationally lensed quasars</h2>\n<p>We have attempted to compile an as-complete-as-possible list of known gravitationally lensed quasars that were published in the literature prior to the <i>Gaia</i> DR2, including some recent candidates that are not yet spectroscopically confirmed. The major source of known gravitational lenses included in our list is the CASTLES (CfA-Arizona Space Telescope LEns Survey of gravitational lenses) site (<a name=\"InR51\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R51\">Kochanek et al. 1999</a>)<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#FN3\">1</a></sup> providing information for about 100 lenses, most of them observed with HST. Another important single source of known multiply imaged quasars is the SDSS Quasar Lens Search site (SQLS)<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#FN4\">2</a></sup>, aimed to discover lensed quasars from the large homogeneous data of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) providing data on 49 additional lensed systems. We also included several quasar systems from the Master Lens Database (<a name=\"InR78\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R78\">Moustakas 2012</a>)<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#FN5\">3</a></sup>, a community-supported compilation of all discovered strong gravitational lenses. Finally we complemented our list with recent and more scattered discoveries from the literature. This list is being kept up-to-date, and will be maintained at least until the final <i>Gaia</i> data release. For the sake of completeness, we also included in this list the candidates with indication in the literature of just one image (usually spectroscopic candidates) expecting from the exceptional resolving power of <i>Gaia</i> that it may resolve some of them into multiple images in one of its data releases.</p>\n<p>Our resulting list of published lensed or lens-candidate quasars contains 481 systems (233 confirmed systems and 248 lensed quasar candidates). This list is only available in electronic form at the CDS, including access through Virtual Observatory ready tools, it comprises lens identifiers, references and the <i>Gaia</i> astrometry and photometry when a match was found in the DR2. A subset of our list is presented in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T4\">B.1</a> (quadruply imaged quasars with at least one detection in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2). The summarised statistical properties of our entire list in terms of number of systems with 1, 2, 3, and 4 and more images and status are given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T1\">1</a>.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>3. Gravitationally lensed quasars in <i>Gaia</i> DR2</h2>\n<p>We extracted sources from the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 within a radius of 10&#8243; around each source of our compiled list of known gravitationally lensed quasars using ADQL and the <i>Gaia</i> archive facility at ESAC (<a name=\"InR94\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R94\">Salgado et al. 2017</a>). We obtained the positions (<i>&#945;</i>, <i>&#948;</i>), parallaxes (<i>&#982;</i>), proper-motion components (<i>&#956;<sub>&#945;</sub></i>, <i>&#956;<sub>&#948;</sub></i>) and fluxes in the <i>G</i>, <i>G</i><sub>BP</sub> and <i>G</i><sub>RP</sub> pass-bands (<a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R21\">Evans et al. 2018</a>) along with their respective uncertainties.</p>\n<p>\n<a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1.</span></a><p>Statistics of the known multiply imaged quasars present in our reference list (Col. 2) and of the corresponding detected systems in <i>Gaia</i> DR2 (Col. 3).</p>\n</div></div>\n</p>\n<p>For each individual image of each system, we performed a positional cross-match within a maximum angular separation of 0.5&#8243; between the astrometry found in the literature and the <i>Gaia</i> DR2. We visually inspected all systems one by one, by comparing the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 detections to the system discovery papers and/or archival images from Aladin (<a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R16\">Bonnarel et al. 2000</a>; <a name=\"InR14\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R14\">Boch et al. 2014</a>).</p>\n<p>Of the 481 gravitational lens systems (including candidates), 206 have at least one image matched with a <i>Gaia</i> DR2 source. The overall detection statistics of known systems that result from our examination is given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T1\">1</a>. An all-sky chart in galactic coordinates of the known lenses is shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F1\">1</a> along with a specification of the <i>Gaia</i> detection.</p>\n<p>In Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T4\">B.1</a> we present a subset of our list: the quads for which at least one match was found in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2. The complete list of lenses and detection is available in electronic form only at the CDS.</p>\n<p>Of the 44 known systems with four images (or more), 29 have at least one image detected in <i>Gaia</i> DR2. Within this group, one system has just one image detected, eight have two images, eight have three images and 12 are fully detected with four images seen in the <i>Gaia</i> data around the target direction. In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F5\">A.1</a>, we provide charts for the 12 systems with four detections with the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 positions given relative to the A image (the brightest image in the system discovery pass-band) together with flux ratios. Of those which are fully detected, only five are characterised by sub-milliarcsec astrometry, and are reported in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T2\">2</a>. The faintest image (in <i>G</i> band) of the others is detected but poorly constrained.</p>\n<p>Several quadruply imaged systems were not completely detected, despite the fact that the apparent magnitudes and angular separations of the system images are within <i>Gaia</i>&#8217;s capabilities. For example, this is the case Q2237+030; only two out of its four known components are published in <i>Gaia</i> DR2. The diffraction limited resolving power of the <i>Gaia</i> instrument is &#8764;0.2&#8243;, but as commented in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S1\">1</a>, the effective angular resolution of the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 is much worse than that, attaining at most &#8764;0.4&#8243;, but with completeness of only &#8764;2.2&#8243;. This loss of resolution restricts the detection of the &#8764;2900 lenses predicted by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R24\">Finet &amp; Surdej (2016)</a>. This happens for multiple reasons, all of them at the ground processing stage, as the <i>Gaia</i> raw data cross-matching, the validation of the astrometric solution and the filtering of possible spurious sources. It is expected, however, that at each <i>Gaia</i> data release the effective angular resolution will improve and thus systems with each time smaller angular separations that are not yet separated in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 will be disentangled.</p>\n<p>\n<a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1.</span></a><p>All-sky chart in galactic coordinates with the galactic anti-centre in the <i>middle</i>. The known multiply imaged quasars are indicated in grey. The systems presenting one or two counterparts in <i>Gaia</i> DR2 are surrounded by a green open circle. The systems with three <i>Gaia</i> DR2 detections are indicated with purple filled circles, while the systems with four or more detections are indicated with orange filled circles.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>4. Astrometric properties of the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 gravitationally lensed quasars</h2>\n<p>The images of a quasar produced by strong gravitational lensing are peculiar since they are not independent astronomical sources but multiple images of the same source, possibly with part of the host galaxy visible as small segments of an arc. Accordingly, they can produce some particular astrometric signatures in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 solution, that could be helpful to discover further lensed quasar systems in the <i>Gaia</i> data.</p>\n<p>Of the 382 individual images found in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 coming from the 178 confirmed gravitationally lensed quasars with two or more images, 65 have a <i>Gaia</i> two-parameter astrometric solution, that is, right ascension and declination only (see <a name=\"InR65\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R65\">Lindegren et al. 2018</a> for a description of the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 astrometric solution selection). The other 317 images have complete five-parameter solutions (<i>&#945;</i>, <i>&#948;</i>, <i>&#956;<sub>&#945;</sub></i> cos(<i>&#948;</i>), <i>&#956;<sub>&#948;</sub></i>, <i>&#982;</i>). We investigated the statistical properties of the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 parameters of the multiple images of the known gravitationally lensed quasars, with results shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F2\">2</a>. This figure shows that parallaxes and proper motions of the images resulting from lensing occasionally reach large values for sources expected to have neither parallax nor motion. However, this results from the fact that these images are rather faint, at the limit of the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 sensitivity where the uncertainties from random noise are also large. In addition it may also be that some images are embedded in extended and diffuse structures.</p>\n<p>In a search for multiply imaged quasars in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2, applying a straight astrometric filter aiming at excluding stars from the deviation from zero parallaxes and proper motions weighted by the expected uncertainties, would likely also exclude a large number of images of lenses. So, based on the distribution of these parameters for the known lenses, we established the following softer astrometric cuts, that at the expense of a certain level of stellar contamination, avoid the rejection of genuine lens systems or of one or several images within a system.</p>\n<p><i>Gaia DR2</i> sources that should be accepted in such a search would likely comply with <i>&#982;</i> &#8722; 3<i>&#963;<sub>&#982;</sub></i> &lt; 4 mas and |<i>&#956;</i>| &#8722; 3<i>&#963;<sub>&#956;</sub></i> &lt; 4 mas yr<sup>&#8722;1</sup>. We note here that <i>&#956;</i> stands for <i>&#956;<sub>&#945;</sub></i> cos(<i>&#948;</i>) and <i>&#956;<sub>&#948;</sub></i>.</p>\n<p>Indeed, we also adopted these soft filters in <i>Gaia</i> GraL Paper I (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R55\">Krone-Martins et al. 2018</a>), where we presented the first ever discoveries of quadruply imaged quasar candidates from data of an astrometric space mission. These statistical astrometric properties derived from <i>Gaia</i> measurements are also being used in a large, machine learning based, systematic blind search for lenses in <i>Gaia</i> DR2 (<i>Gaia</i> GraL Paper III; Delchambre et al., in prep.).</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>5. Gravitational lens modelling with sub-mas astrometry</h2>\n<p>Gravitational lensing provides an efficient tool to explore various aspects of our universe and several of its components. In the strong regime, the inference of physically meaningful quantities from observational data usually requires the accurate modelling of the gravitational potential of the deflector. For example, the ability of modern time-delay cosmography to infer the Hubble constant <i>H</i><sub>0</sub> with a competitive precision relies significantly on its capacity in dealing with families of degeneracies existing between different plausible lens mass profiles (<a name=\"InR93\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R93\">Saha 2000</a>; <a name=\"InR109\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R109\">Wucknitz 2002</a>; <a name=\"InR62\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R62\">Liesenborgs &amp; De Rijcke 2012</a>; <a name=\"InR98\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R98\">Schneider &amp; Sluse 2013</a>). To probe the deflector mass distribution in the region where multiple images are formed, simple parameterised mass models are commonly used whose parameters are fixed by the observational constraints (e.g. <a name=\"InR48\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R48\">Keeton 2001</a>, <a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R49\">2010</a>; <a name=\"InR58\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R58\">Lefor &amp; Futamase 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R58\">Lefor 2014</a>), typically the lensed quasar image positions, the morphology of extended components, microlensing-free flux ratios, and time delays between image pairs. Naturally, a better accuracy in the observed parameters leads to a more reliable model. For the five known lenses RXJ1131-1231, SDSS1004+4112, 2MASS J1134-2103, HE0435-1223, and WFI2033-4723, the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 provides quasar image position measurements with an unprecedented precision of a few tenths of a milliarcsecond. With an improvement of an order of magnitude over typical HST astrometric accuracy, these new astrometric data should help to better constrain the lens models. Considering four of the five known quadruply imaged quasars reported in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T2\">2</a> for which <i>Gaia</i> and HST astrometric data are available, the average of the <i>Gaia</i> astrometric uncertainties affecting the equatorial coordinates of the four lensed quasar images is found to be 0.43 mas compared to 3.29 mas using the corresponding HST data. This represents a huge gain (by more than a factor 7) in astrometric precision.</p>\n<p>\n<a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2.</span></a><p>Distributions of the astrometric parameters and their uncertainties for all the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 counterparts of the individual images of known multiply imaged quasars with five parameter astrometric solutions.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</p>\n<p>\n<a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3.</span></a><p>Results of the MCMC simulations for HE0435-1223, displayed as a corner plot for the five model parameters. Results obtained from <i>Gaia</i>&#8217;s data are presented in red and with HST data in grey. The diagonal panels illustrate the posterior PDFs while the off-axis panels illustrate the correlation between the parameters. The three inner contours represent the 68.3%, 95.4%, and 99.7% confidence intervals.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</p>\n<p>\n<a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4.</span></a><p>Results of the MCMC simulations for HE0435-1223, displayed as a corner plot for the source and deflector positions. Results obtained from <i>Gaia</i>&#8217;s data are presented in red and with HST data in grey. The diagonal panels The diagonal panels illustrate the posterior PDFs while the off-axis panels illustrate the correlation between the parameters. The three inner contours represent the 68.3%, 95.4%, and 99.7% confidence intervals.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</p>\n<p>In this section, we illustrate how the improved astrometric accuracy obtained with <i>Gaia</i> may impact the lens modelling. To this end, we propose to optimise a smooth model to the observed image positions alone, within the Bayesian framework. The idea consists in simultaneously sampling the posterior probability density functions (PDFs) for all model parameters using a Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method, and then comparing the PDFs obtained from <i>Gaia</i>&#8217;s astrometry with the ones derived from the astrometry found in the literature. We want to point out that our objective here is not to construct a set of realistic lens models in the sense that they could be used to perform time delay cosmography. Instead, we have focussed on how <i>Gaia</i> astrometric uncertainties may positively affect the goodness of a more complex fit, which would include microlensing-free flux ratios, time delays, non-lensing data related to the main deflector, or even simultaneous reconstruction of the source and deflector surface brightnesses.</p>\n<p>We model the main deflector as a singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE, see e.g. <a name=\"InR53\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R53\">Kormann et al. 1994</a>) which effectively describes the mass distribution of a massive early-type galaxy in the region where multiple images are formed (<a name=\"InR30\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R30\">Gilman et al. 2017</a>). A SIE is characterised by five free parameters; the Einstein radius <i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub>, the elliptical axes ratio <i>q</i> and position angle <i>&#952;<sub>q</sub></i>, and the lens centroid (<i>x</i><sub>G</sub>, <i>y</i><sub>G</sub>) with respect to image A. Since the lensed quasar image positions are generally most sensitive to the local mass distribution, we model the large-scale contributions and possible close line-of-sight galaxy perturbing effects with an external shear term (g) characterised by its absolute value <i>&#947;</i> and position angle <i>&#952;<sub>&#947;</sub></i> (see e.g., <a name=\"InR50\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R50\">Kochanek et al. 2006</a>). The resulting SIEg model is thus kept simple, which limits the number of free parameters and avoids the use of the full multi-plane lensing formalism (<a name=\"InR97\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R97\">Schneider 2014</a>; <a name=\"InR69\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R69\">McCully et al. 2014</a>, <a name=\"InR70\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R70\">2016</a>). In addition, we consider the position of the point-like source (<i>&#946;<sub>x</sub></i>, <i>&#946;<sub>y</sub></i>) with respect to image A that is also free to vary during the optimization process, bringing the number of free parameters <i>n<sub>k</sub></i> to nine.</p>\n<p>To draw samples from the posterior PDFs, we used <tt>emcee</tt><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#FN6\">4</a></sup> (<a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R25\">Foreman-Mackey et al. 2013</a>), a python package which implements the affine invariant ensemble sampler for MCMC proposed by <a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R32\">Goodman &amp; Weare (2010)</a>. Since we only used the lensed image positions <i><b>&#952;</b></i><sub>obs</sub> as observational data to fit, the log-likelihood function simply reads</p>\n<p>\n<a name=\"FD1\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq1\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-eq1.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(1)</span></span>\n</p>\n<p>where <i><b>k</b></i> is the vector of free parameters, <i>N</i> the number of lensed images (hence 2<i>N</i> constraints), <i>&#963;</i><sub>obs</sub> the astrometric uncertainties, and <i><b>&#952;</b></i><sub>model</sub>(<i><b>k</b></i>) the lensed image positions obtained from the free parameters <i><b>k</b></i> and generated with the python package <tt>pySPT</tt><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#FN7\">5</a></sup> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R55\">Wertz &amp; Orthen 2018</a>). To control the sampling, only two hyperparameters need to be tuned: an adjustable scale parameter <i>a</i> and the number <i>N</i><sub>w</sub> of walkers. The scale parameter <i>a</i> has a direct impact on the acceptance rate of each walker, namely the ratio of accepted to proposed candidates, and was set to <i>a</i> = 2, following <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R32\">Goodman &amp; Weare (2010)</a>. A walker can be seen as a Metropolis-Hastings chain (see, e.g., <a name=\"InR67\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R67\">MacKay 2003</a>) whose associated proposal distribution depends on the positions of all the other walkers (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R25\">Foreman-Mackey et al. 2013</a>). Prior to run the MCMC, we initialised <i>N</i><sub>w</sub> = 350 walkers in a small <i>n<sub>k</sub></i>-dimensional ball of the parameter space around a highly probable solution, formerly obtained using the public lens modelling code <tt>lensmodel</tt><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#FN8\">6</a></sup> (v1.99, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R48\">Keeton 2001</a>). Obviously this initial model may not be the most appropriate one and is more likely a local solution in the parameter space. Nevertheless, it constitutes a valid starting point to illustrate our intention.</p>\n<p>The analysis has been performed for the five lenses from Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T2\">2</a> for which HST image position measurements are available, namely HE0435-1223, SDSS1004+4112, RXJ1131-1231, 2MASS J1134-2103, and WFI2033-4723. In Figs. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F3\">3</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F4\">4</a>, we illustrate the MCMC results in the form of corner plots for HE0435-1223, which are representative of each of the five quadruply imaged quasars that we have preliminarily modelled. The HE0435-1223 image positions measured with the Wide Field Camera 3 (IR/F160W, <a name=\"InR90\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R90\">Robberto et al. 2002</a>) mounted on the HST come from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R50\">Kochanek et al. (2006)</a>, showing astrometric uncertainties between 3 and 5 mas. As expected, all the posterior PDFs obtained from the <i>Gaia</i> data show narrower widths than those obtained from HST data, while some of them are slightly shifted. Thus the use of <i>Gaia</i> astrometry data significantly reduces the ranges of valid model parameters around a highly probable solution, as shown in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T3\">3</a>. The Einstein radius value has only been slightly improved with respect to HST observations, while the source position is constrained within a <i>&#963;</i>-error ellipse of (<i>&#963;<sub>&#946;<sub>x</sub></sub></i>, <i>&#963;<sub>&#946;<sub>y</sub></sub></i>) = (0.1,0.1) mas. This one order of magnitude improvement indicates that the sub-mas astrometry of <i>Gaia</i> clearly helps to better constrain the position of the point-like source as well as the source surface brightness reconstruction as part of a more realistic modelling scenario.</p>\n<p>We also note that the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 astrometry reduces significantly the resulting correlation structure between the modelled parameters, in comparison with the correlations obtained from the modelling using HST data: the absolute value of the correlation coefficients between <i>&#952;<sub>q</sub></i> and <i>&#952;<sub>&#947;</sub></i>, and <i>&#952;<sub>q</sub></i> and <i>q</i>, in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F3\">3</a> and between <i>&#946;<sub>y</sub></i> and <i>y</i><sub>G</sub>, and <i>&#946;<sub>x</sub></i> and <i>x</i><sub>G</sub> in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F4\">4</a>, are clearly reduced thanks to the improved astrometry.</p>\n<p>A more advanced version of the lens modelling within the Bayesian framework described in this section will be consistently applied to all the known lenses and to the highly probable lens candidates discovered from a systematic search around quasars (<i>Gaia</i> GraL Paper I, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R55\">Krone-Martins et al. 2018</a>) and from the systematic blind-search for lenses in the entire <i>Gaia</i> DR2 (<i>Gaia</i> GraL Paper III, Delchambre et al., in prep.), and this will be presented in a forthcoming work (<i>Gaia</i> GraL Paper IV, Wertz et al., in prep.).</p>\n<p>\n<a name=\"T3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3.</span></a><p>SIEg lens model parameters derived for HE0435-1223.</p>\n</div></div>\n</p>\n<a name=\"T2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2.</span></a><p>Relative astrometry for five known quadruply imaged quasars fully detected in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</p>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>6. Conclusions</h2>\n<p>The availability of high-precision and high-accuracy astrometric data as provided by the ESA/<i>Gaia</i> space mission opens a new window to detect and model gravitationally lensed quasar systems with an unprecedented refinement. This is bound to impact on fundamental applications in astronomy that are derived from this phenomena, such as the study of the lensing galaxy populations, distant quasars, dark matter and dark energy properties and consequently the determination of cosmological parameters. To exploit this new field with the <i>Gaia</i> data, we have set up a collaboration group, the <i>Gaia</i> GraL team, to systematically analyse the gravitationally lensed quasar content throughout the <i>Gaia</i> data releases. The topics covered include searches for new multiply imaged quasar candidates, identifications of known lenses in the <i>Gaia</i> data, modelling of the lenses using the outstanding <i>Gaia</i> astrometry and multi-colour photometry, and fostering ground-based follow-up for final confirmation.</p>\n<p>In this paper we explain how we first generated an up-to-date list of known gravitationally lensed quasars, including lensed quasars too faint to be observed by <i>Gaia</i>. The <i>Gaia</i> GraL list of known gravitationally lensed quasars will be kept up-to-date with respect to the astronomical literature at least until the final <i>Gaia</i> data release. Each <i>Gaia</i> data release will be analysed to verify the detection of known gravitational lenses.</p>\n<p>Then we provide here the first ever sub-milliarcsecond astrometric data for hundreds of known gravitationally lensed quasars. The search is based on the aforementioned list matched to the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 astrometric catalogue, the largest and most precise astrometric reference available to date. Our lens results bring almost one order of magnitude improvement in astrometric precision compared to a typical HST observation. Moreover, even if <i>Gaia</i> DR2 is still an early data release lacking many lensed images, it brings high-precision astrometry complemented with photometric data for most known lensed systems. Thus, it provides a glimpse of the content that will become available in the forthcoming <i>Gaia</i> data releases.</p>\n<p>Of the 481 presently known or candidate gravitationally lensed quasars, we have found in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 at least one counterpart for 206 of them. From these objects, the quadruply-imaged quasars occupy a specially relevant place, as they provide the more stringent physical parameter inferences. There are 44 presently known quads. From these, 29 have been found with at least one entry in <i>Gaia</i> DR2 and 12 of them are fully detected with all four images. As the images of many of these objects have smaller angular separations than the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 effective angular resolution, we expect the forthcoming data releases to provide information for most images with separations down to &#8764;0.18&#8243;, as the <i>Gaia</i> releases gradually reach the instrument spatial resolution. We also provide <i>Gaia</i> DR2 astrometric and photometric data for all known lenses to date.</p>\n<p>Finally, we show that the adoption of high-precision astrometry from <i>Gaia</i> DR2 to model the well-known lens system HE0435-1223 results in a significant improvement in constraining the lens parameters of a SIEg model around a highly probable solution, and that it also significantly reduces the model parameter correlations, in comparison to standard HST astrometry. Such constraints will certainly be further improved with the increased precision of forthcoming <i>Gaia</i> nominal mission data releases, expected for 2020 (DR3) and 2022 (DR4), and the still to be announced data release(s) of the <i>Gaia</i> mission extension.</p>\n<p>As a final conclusion this work vividly demonstrates the significant impact of high-precision astrometry from <i>Gaia</i> and future mission concepts as the JASMINE series (<a name=\"InR33\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R33\">Gouda 2011</a>), GaiaNIR (<a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R35\">Hobbs et al. 2016</a>), and Theia (The Theia <a name=\"InR102\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#R102\">Collaboration et al. 2017</a>), to the study of strong gravitational lensing. This paper also exemplifies the ever wider impact of astrometry and of the <i>Gaia</i> satellite, pushing its limits from its original goal of studying the Milky Way galaxy towards more distant extragalactic sources and associated phenomena.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ack\"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>\n<p>The authors wish to thank the referee for his constructive comments. AKM acknowledges the support from the Portuguese Funda&#231;&#227;o para a Ci&#234;ncia e a Tecnologia (FCT) through grants SFRH/BPD/74697/2010, from the Portuguese Strategic Programme UID/FIS/00099/2013 for CENTRA, from the ESA contract AO/1-7836/14/NL/HB and from the Caltech Division of Physics, Mathematics and Astronomy for hosting a research leave during 2017-2018, when this paper was prepared. LD and JS acknowledge support from the ESA PRODEX Programme &#8220;<i>Gaia</i>-DPAC QSOs&#8221; and from the Belgian Federal Science Policy Office. OW acknowledges support from a fellowship for Postdoctoral Researchers by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation. Some of the authors are members of the <i>Gaia</i> Data Processing and Analysis Consortium (DPAC).</p>\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN3\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://www.cfa.harvard.edu/castles/\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cfa.harvard.edu/castles/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN4\"></a><sup>2</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"http://www-utap.phys.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp/~sdss/sqls/lens.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://www-utap.phys.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp/~sdss/sqls/lens.html</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN5\"></a><sup>3</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"http://admin.masterlens.org/index.php?\" target=\"_blank\">http://admin.masterlens.org/index.php?</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN6\"></a><sup>4</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://github.com/dfm/emcee\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/dfm/emcee</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN7\"></a><sup>5</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://github.com/owertz/pySPT\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/owertz/pySPT</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN8\"></a><sup>6</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"http://physics.rutgers.edu/~keeton/gravlens/2012WS/\" target=\"_blank\">http://physics.rutgers.edu/~keeton/gravlens/2012WS/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ref\"></a>References</h2>\n    <div id=\"content\">\n        <ol class=\"references\">\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R1\"></a>Agnello, A., Kelly, B. N. Manset, &amp; P. Forshay, ASp Conf. Ser., 485, 277\n\n                \n                \n                \n                                    <a href=\"https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Astronomical+Data+Analysis+Software+and+Systems+XXIII&author=Boch%2C+T.%2C+%26amp%3B+Fernique%2C+P.%2C+in+%2C+eds.+N.+Manset%2C+%26amp%3B+P.+Forshay&journal=ASp+Conf.+Ser.&volume=485&pages=277&publication_year=2014\">[Google&nbsp;Scholar]</a>\n                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R15\"></a>Bolton, A. S., Moustakas, L. A., Stern, D., et al. 2006, ApJ, 646, L45\n\n                \n                                                            <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/#abs/2006ApJ...646L..45B/abstract\">\n                                                    [NASA ADS]\n                                                </a>\n                                                                                <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.1086/506446\">\n                                                    [CrossRef]\n                                                </a>\n                                    \n                \n                                    <a        \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                </ol>\n    </div>\n\n\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix A:  <i>Gaia</i> DR2 finding charts of known and confirmed quadruply-imaged quasars</h2>\n<p>\n<a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. A.1.</span></a><p>Finding charts for the known GLs with four counterparts in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2. <i>Gaia</i> DR2 astrometry relative to the brightest image (A image) based on the original system discovery data is indicated by black points (except WGD2038-4008, see footnote in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T4\">B.1</a>). The numbers near each image, and the image size, indicate the flux ratios to the brightest image in the original system discovery data. We note that in some cases this may not be the brightest image detected by <i>Gaia</i> and therefore generates some flux ratios &gt;1. North is up, east is left.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix B  </h2>\n<a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table B.1.</span></a><p>List of known quadruply-imaged quasars with at least one match in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</p>\n</div></div>\n\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"tabs\"></a>All Tables</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1.</span></a><p>Statistics of the known multiply imaged quasars present in our reference list (Col. 2) and of the corresponding detected systems in <i>Gaia</i> DR2 (Col. 3).</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T1\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2.</span></a><p>Relative astrometry for five known quadruply imaged quasars fully detected in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T2\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3.</span></a><p>SIEg lens model parameters derived for HE0435-1223.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T3\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table B.1.</span></a><p>List of known quadruply-imaged quasars with at least one match in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T4\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"figs\"></a>All Figures</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1.</span></a><p>All-sky chart in galactic coordinates with the galactic anti-centre in the <i>middle</i>. The known multiply imaged quasars are indicated in grey. The systems presenting one or two counterparts in <i>Gaia</i> DR2 are surrounded by a green open circle. The systems with three <i>Gaia</i> DR2 detections are indicated with purple filled circles, while the systems with four or more detections are indicated with orange filled circles.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F1\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2.</span></a><p>Distributions of the astrometric parameters and their uncertainties for all the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 counterparts of the individual images of known multiply imaged quasars with five parameter astrometric solutions.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F2\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3.</span></a><p>Results of the MCMC simulations for HE0435-1223, displayed as a corner plot for the five model parameters. Results obtained from <i>Gaia</i>&#8217;s data are presented in red and with HST data in grey. The diagonal panels illustrate the posterior PDFs while the off-axis panels illustrate the correlation between the parameters. The three inner contours represent the 68.3%, 95.4%, and 99.7% confidence intervals.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F3\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4.</span></a><p>Results of the MCMC simulations for HE0435-1223, displayed as a corner plot for the source and deflector positions. Results obtained from <i>Gaia</i>&#8217;s data are presented in red and with HST data in grey. The diagonal panels The diagonal panels illustrate the posterior PDFs while the off-axis panels illustrate the correlation between the parameters. The three inner contours represent the 68.3%, 95.4%, and 99.7% confidence intervals.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F4\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. A.1.</span></a><p>Finding charts for the known GLs with four counterparts in the <i>Gaia</i> DR2. <i>Gaia</i> DR2 astrometry relative to the brightest image (A image) based on the original system discovery data is indicated by black points (except WGD2038-4008, see footnote in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#T4\">B.1</a>). The numbers near each image, and the image size, indicate the flux ratios to the brightest image in the original system discovery data. We note that in some cases this may not be the brightest image detected by <i>Gaia</i> and therefore generates some flux ratios &gt;1. North is up, east is left.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#F5\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</div>\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\" data-edps_ref=\"aa33480-18\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. II. The known multiply imaged quasars", "authors": ["Ducourant, C.", "Wertz, O.", "Krone-Martins, A.", "Teixeira, R.", "Le Campion, J. -F.", "Galluccio, L.", "Kl\u00fcter, J.", "Delchambre, L.", "Surdej, J.", "Mignard, F.", "Wambsganss, J.", "Bastian, U.", "Graham, M. J.", "Djorgovski, S. G.", "Slezak, E."], "author_address": ["AA(Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Bordeaux, Univ. Bordeaux, CNRS, B18N, all\u00e9e Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 33615, Pessac, France), AB(Argelander-Institut f\u00fcr Astronomie, Universit\u00e4t Bonn, Auf dem H\u00fcgel 71, 53121, Bonn, Germany), AC(CENTRA, Faculdade de Ci\u00eancias, Universidade de Lisboa, Ed. C8, Campo Grande, 1749-016, Lisboa, Portugal), AD(Instituto de Astronomia, Geof\u00edsica e Ci\u00eancias Atmosf\u00e9ricas, Universidade de S\u00e3o Paulo, Rua do Mat\u00e3o, 1226, Cidade Universit\u00e1ria, 05508-900, S\u00e3o Paulo, SP, Brazil), AE(Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Bordeaux, Univ. Bordeaux, CNRS, B18N, all\u00e9e Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 33615, Pessac, France), AF(Universit\u00e9 C\u00f4te d'Azur, Observatoire de la C\u00f4te d'Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire Lagrange, Boulevard de l'Observatoire, CS 34229, 06304 Nice, France), AG(Zentrum f\u00fcr Astronomie der Universit\u00e4t Heidelberg, Astronomisches Rechen-Institut, M\u00f6nchhofstr. 12-14, 69120, Heidelberg, Germany), AH(Institut d'Astrophysique et de G\u00e9ophysique, Universit\u00e9 de Li\u00e8ge, 19c, All\u00e9e du 6 Ao\u00fbt, 4000, Li\u00e8ge, Belgium), AI(Institut d'Astrophysique et de G\u00e9ophysique, Universit\u00e9 de Li\u00e8ge, 19c, All\u00e9e du 6 Ao\u00fbt, 4000, Li\u00e8ge, Belgium), AJ(Universit\u00e9 C\u00f4te d'Azur, Observatoire de la C\u00f4te d'Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire Lagrange, Boulevard de l'Observatoire, CS 34229, 06304 Nice, France), AK(Zentrum f\u00fcr Astronomie der Universit\u00e4t Heidelberg, Astronomisches Rechen-Institut, M\u00f6nchhofstr. 12-14, 69120, Heidelberg, Germany; International Space Science Institute (ISSI), Hallerstra\u00dfe 6, 3012, Bern, Switzerland), AL(Zentrum f\u00fcr Astronomie der Universit\u00e4t Heidelberg, Astronomisches Rechen-Institut, M\u00f6nchhofstr. 12-14, 69120, Heidelberg, Germany), AM(California Institute of Technology, 1200 E. California Blvd, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA), AN(California Institute of Technology, 1200 E. California Blvd, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA), AO(Universit\u00e9 C\u00f4te d'Azur, Observatoire de la C\u00f4te d'Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire Lagrange, Boulevard de l'Observatoire, CS 34229, 06304 Nice, France)"], "journal_name": "Astronomy and Astrophysics", "volume": "618", "publication_year": "2018/10/1", "start_page": "A56", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "astrometry"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018A&A...618A..56D", "abstract": "Context. Thanks to its spatial resolution, the ESA/Gaia space mission offers a unique opportunity to discover new multiply imaged quasars and to study the already known lensed systems at sub-milliarcsecond astrometric precisions. <BR /> Aims: In this paper, we address the detection of the known multiply imaged quasars from the Gaia Data Release 2 (DR2) and determine the astrometric and photometric properties of the individually detected images found in the Gaia DR2 catalogue. <BR /> Methods: We have compiled an exhaustive list of quasar gravitational lenses from the literature to search for counterparts in the Gaia DR2. We then analysed the astrometric and photometric properties of these Gaia's detections. To highlight the tremendous potential of Gaia at the sub-milliarcsecond level we finally performed a simple Bayesian modelling of the well-known gravitational lens system HE0435-1223, using Gaia DR2 and HST astrometry. <BR /> Results: From 481 known multiply imaged quasars, 206 have at least one image found in the Gaia DR2. Among the 44 known quadruply imaged quasars of the list, 29 have at least one image in the Gaia DR2, 12 of which are fully detected (2MASX J01471020+4630433, HE 0435-1223, SDSS1004+4112, PG1115+080, RXJ1131-1231, 2MASS J11344050-2103230, 2MASS J13102005-1714579, B1422+231, J1606-2333, J1721+8842, WFI2033-4723, WGD2038-4008), eight have three counterparts, eight have two and one has only one. As expected, the modelling of HE0435-1223 shows that the model parameters are significantly better constrained when using Gaia astrometry compared to HST astrometry, in particular the relative positions of the background quasar source and the centroid of the deflector. The Gaia sub-milliarcsecond astrometry also significantly reduces the parameter correlations. <BR /> Conclusions: Besides providing an up-to-date list of multiply imaged quasars and their detection in the Gaia DR2, this paper shows that more complex modelling scenarios will certainly benefit from Gaia sub-milliarcsecond astrometry. <P />The table of lenses (confirmed and candidates, detected or not in Gaia DR2) is only available at the CDS via anonymous ftp to <A href=\"http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr\">http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr</A> (ftp://130.79.128.5) or via <A href=\"http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/qcat?J/A+A/618/A56\">http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/qcat?J/A+A/618/A56</A>. A subset of this table is presented in Table B.1.", "doi": "10.1051/0004-6361/201833480", "issn": "0004-6361"}, "Table meta data": {"Table set 0": {"Link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2018A&A...618A..56D/PUB_HTML", "Response": "<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html xml:lang=\"en-gb\" lang=\"en-gb\" dir=\"ltr\">\n<head>\n    <meta name=\"viewport\" content=\"width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0, shrink-to-fit=no\">\n      <base href=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html\" />\n  <meta http-equiv=\"content-type\" content=\"text/html; charset=utf-8\" />\n  <meta name=\"keywords\" content=\"Astronomy &amp; Astrophysics, A&amp;A, ESO, EDP Sciences\" />\n  <meta name=\"robots\" content=\"index, follow, noarchive\" />\n  <meta name=\"description\" content=\"Astronomy &amp; Astrophysics (A&amp;A) is an international journal which publishes papers on all aspects of astronomy and astrophysics\" />\n  <title>Gaia GraL: Gaia DR2 gravitational lens systems - II. California Blvd, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"E. Slezak\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Universit\u00e9 C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur, Observatoire de la C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire Lagrange, Boulevard de l\u2019Observatoire, CS 34229, 06304 Nice, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"Gaia GraL: Gaia DR2 gravitational lens systems - II. The known multiply imaged quasars\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2018/10/12\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2018/10/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"618\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A56\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2018A%26A...618A..56D\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2018/10/aa33480-18.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"astrometry\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context&lt;i/&gt;. Thanks to its spatial resolution, the ESA/&lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; space mission offers a unique opportunity to discover new multiply imaged quasars and to study the already known lensed systems at sub-milliarcsecond astrometric precisions.&lt;i&gt;Aims&lt;i/&gt;. In this paper, we address the detection of the known multiply imaged quasars from the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; Data Release 2 (DR2) and determine the astrometric and photometric properties of the individually detected images found in the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 catalogue.&lt;i&gt;Methods&lt;i/&gt;. We have compiled an exhaustive list of quasar gravitational lenses from the literature to search for counterparts in the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2. We then analysed the astrometric and photometric properties of these &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt;\u2019s detections. To highlight the tremendous potential of &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; at the sub-milliarcsecond level we finally performed a simple Bayesian modelling of the well-known gravitational lens system HE0435-1223, using &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 and HST astrometry.&lt;i&gt;Results&lt;i/&gt;. From 481 known multiply imaged quasars, 206 have at least one image found in the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2. Among the 44 known quadruply imaged quasars of the list, 29 have at least one image in the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2, 12 of which are fully detected (2MASX J01471020+4630433, HE 0435-1223, SDSS1004+4112, PG1115+080, RXJ1131-1231, 2MASS J11344050-2103230, 2MASS J13102005-1714579, B1422+231, J1606-2333, J1721+8842, WFI2033-4723, WGD2038-4008), eight have three counterparts, eight have two and one has only one. As expected, the modelling of HE0435-1223 shows that the model parameters are significantly better constrained when using &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; astrometry compared to HST astrometry, in particular the relative positions of the background quasar source and the centroid of the deflector. The &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; sub-milliarcsecond astrometry also significantly reduces the parameter correlations.&lt;i&gt;Conclusions&lt;i/&gt;. Besides providing an up-to-date list of multiply imaged quasars and their detection in the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2, this paper shows that more complex modelling scenarios will certainly benefit from &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; sub-milliarcsecond astrometry.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A. Agnello;citation_author=B. C. Kelly;citation_author=T. Treu;citation_author=P. J. Marshall;citation_publication_date=2015;citation_journal_title=MNRAS;citation_volume=448;citation_firstpage=1446;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"Agnello, A., Lin, H., &amp; Kuropatkin, N. 2017, MNRAS, in press\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A.             dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: data</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>DOI</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\">\n\t\t\t\t\thttps://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201833480\n\t\t\t\t</a>\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Published online</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t12 October 2018\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t</table>\n</div>\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"article\">\r\n    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\">\n\n<div class=\"menu\" id=\"bloc\"><ul>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#top_full\">Top</a></li>\n<li><a Introduction</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2018/10/aa33480-18/aa33480-18.html#S2\" title=\"Compiled list of gravitationally lensed quasars\">2.
